MEssns. EDIToRs The following suggestions
are thrown out for the benefit OF those concerned.


The States Of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and
Delaware, have solicited the government a. Wash
ington' to erect breakwater at the mouth Of Del
| aware Bay. These " sovereign and inde PENDENT
States have shown from time to time that this work
ia" essential to their commercial prosperity. thst
they have paid more into the treasury OF the gov
ernmen, al Washington" ia proportion 10 what they
have received, than any three States in this unhap.
py Union. That government has "hnughtly' ne
elected compliance with their . Just demands"
| Now, Sirs, ask, is it to be endured that these
sovereign aud independent States to be treat
ed thus Will they submit to such contumey ~
Srs, there is a remedy, thanks to Georgia and
Governor Troup. A little bullying will do the
business; beg pardon Of his high mighiiness CO.
vernon Troup and Mr. Forsy.he & Co., mean
lew decent uianestocs smacking Of war, division,
blood and thunder, backed BY the Hancock troop
OF horse" will soon bring the Tyrants at Wash
ingion to their senses.


| Sirs, the case OF Georgia presents an example
which specially recommend TO the observance
and imitation of oppressed States, in all future
time.


Georgia was grievously oppressed by parcel
oi Choctsws, Cherokees, Kangaroos, Pot,awatta-
mits, and other people with red skins and horrible
names, living IN her bosom, and owning excellent
lduu, WuiIu tuC pdtTioNC WcIc, very na-
turally, extremely anxious to possess. Well Sirs,
what did they dol Why, they told The Washington
Jnnto. that they must and would have the lands !;
that these red skinned people must be off. or they
would extnguish them; in plain English, cut their
throas-and they paroded the Hancock chivalry.
Well, Sirs, .he Washington people were frightened
and justice done to the suffering Georgians.
The red raggamuAins are to be driven, men, women
and children, from the homes OF their fathers. the
land ~ Had tt,.
have them az act OF national Justice and beneyo
lence which has no parallel since the deportation Of
the MooFs OF Spain and the d,agoonng of the Hu
guennts Of France and besides the government
al Washington" has been obliged to pay since
BOZ to the tune Of nearly 1000 900 dollars for the
benefit of Georgia. There, Sirs, is justice, even
handed justice.


After this, the age Of Chivalry is gone" in
deed, if we have not a breakwater. What are our
Governors about Where be our congressman,
our slang whsngers, our captains Of tens and oil
fiiies. cockboats, torpedoes, birthstone
and sa,petre, and where is Colonel Plucks Is
here other champion of State rights, be found
than Governor Troupf


! Lei the united voice Of Pennsylvania, Delaware
and New Jersey proclaim in tones Of thunder, to
the 9. base and infamous white men a, Washing
ton that " there is alternatiye' between break.
wafer and i" exnc,ion.' No more sneaking, no
more dancing attendance at Washington let US put
our hands in and help ourselves.


STATE RIGHTS.

import

cannot be injurious either to the individual or to Socie

the innocent inrmites of the votares Of religion and v


tue But although skepticsm doubling, may be good
besnlng in philosophy and may be deemed innocent IN


tile commencement yet the end is awful to many and its
Effects Society tieelerous 1t would be much
better be philosopher at all, and to continue in the
common herd Of mankind. than to embrace those subl


ties in metaphy sizes, which envelope all those great and
important truths OF reason and religion III mss OF doubt


But a doctrine peculiarly commodous all our young
and smaterersn eetnnking Il has shaken those
foundations which the whole moral world. and the great
fabric of social happiness entirely rest Believe me, 1t IS
only true rational, and virtuous philosophy, which gives
virtue its sweetest hopes TO mpenten vice its greatest


fears, and to penesce its best consostions and
makes those allowances for the nhrmes Of nature, which
some are pleased call superstition We should certain

their utmost improvement and expansion, would allow us
to go and always to keep them within the precincts OF

full articles.headline: 40 DOLLARS REWARD.
full articles.article:
DAN AWAY from the subscriber living Cantwell's
man named Robert Colbay Wallace, about % years
old has about years serve and nearly feet hg


complexion toleraby black, has large scar over the
left ear caused by fall from horsewaks straight, his
head rather ncnng back smooth face, has used
razor-good countenance, and pleasant when spoken to
short nose, an6 toeraby quick spoken; generally very
quick and active on foot has been raised to farming
altogether He took away with him suit Of homemade
rab cloth. pretty well and patched the left side or
appe of the coat had been and piece inserted
also new and panaets of dab cloth, with
yellow buttons the coat and great coat of the same
nearly new two three pairs Of thick, mixed home
made stockings, and an oil fur hat


A colored man calling himself Henry Hat'ace, who said
he was brother Robert, (and who, it s believed, lives
in Chester Lancaster County. Penn came to my house
on the evening of the 23d nst and suppose persuaded
him away He is said to be taller than Robert and not
quite SO black Whoever will the two in jail, so
that can get Robert and bring the other to JUSTICE shall
receive the above reward and all necessary charges
Twenty Dollars and reasonable charges for either of them


ALEXANDER MCAULLEY.

full articles.headline:
- MODfDe -.

FOR THE wATcHmAs.
full articles.article:
MEssns. EDIToRs The following suggestions
are thrown out for the benefit OF those concerned.


The States Of Pennsylvania, New Jersey, and
Delaware, have solicited the government a. Wash
ington' to erect breakwater at the mouth Of Del
| aware Bay. These " sovereign and inde PENDENT
States have shown from time to time that this work
ia" essential to their commercial prosperity. thst
they have paid more into the treasury OF the gov
ernmen, al Washington" ia proportion 10 what they
have received, than any three States in this unhap.
py Union. That government has "hnughtly' ne
elected compliance with their . Just demands"
| Now, Sirs, ask, is it to be endured that these
sovereign aud independent States to be treat
ed thus Will they submit to such contumey ~
Srs, there is a remedy, thanks to Georgia and
Governor Troup. A little bullying will do the
business; beg pardon Of his high mighiiness CO.
vernon Troup and Mr. Forsy.he & Co., mean
lew decent uianestocs smacking Of war, division,
blood and thunder, backed BY the Hancock troop
OF horse" will soon bring the Tyrants at Wash
ingion to their senses.


| Sirs, the case OF Georgia presents an example
which specially recommend TO the observance
and imitation of oppressed States, in all future
time.


Georgia was grievously oppressed by parcel
oi Choctsws, Cherokees, Kangaroos, Pot,awatta-
mits, and other people with red skins and horrible
names, living IN her bosom, and owning excellent
lduu, WuiIu tuC pdtTioNC WcIc, very na-
turally, extremely anxious to possess. Well Sirs,
what did they dol Why, they told The Washington
Jnnto. that they must and would have the lands !;
that these red skinned people must be off. or they
would extnguish them; in plain English, cut their
throas-and they paroded the Hancock chivalry.
Well, Sirs, .he Washington people were frightened
and justice done to the suffering Georgians.
The red raggamuAins are to be driven, men, women
and children, from the homes OF their fathers. the
land ~ Had tt,.
have them az act OF national Justice and beneyo
lence which has no parallel since the deportation Of
the MooFs OF Spain and the d,agoonng of the Hu
guennts Of France and besides the government
al Washington" has been obliged to pay since
BOZ to the tune Of nearly 1000 900 dollars for the
benefit of Georgia. There, Sirs, is justice, even
handed justice.


After this, the age Of Chivalry is gone" in
deed, if we have not a breakwater. What are our
Governors about Where be our congressman,
our slang whsngers, our captains Of tens and oil
fiiies. cockboats, torpedoes, birthstone
and sa,petre, and where is Colonel Plucks Is
here other champion of State rights, be found
than Governor Troupf


! Lei the united voice Of Pennsylvania, Delaware
and New Jersey proclaim in tones Of thunder, to
the 9. base and infamous white men a, Washing
ton that " there is alternatiye' between break.
wafer and i" exnc,ion.' No more sneaking, no
more dancing attendance at Washington let US put
our hands in and help ourselves.


STATE RIGHTS.


'see Mr. Forsyth and Governor 1'roup, pass,m.

MORGAN AcA1N.--The Orleans Advocate ofthe
18th inst says, two gentlemen stopped at the
house OF Mr.. Curtis in Games, in this county, The
18th who stated that they we're their way with
dispatches from Sir p. Maitland, Lieut.. Gov. of
Upper Canada. TO Gov. Clinton, announcing thas
Witttam Morgan was in the possession Of the for
mer, subject TO the direction Of the latter aire aud
meH. They also stated that they saw and conver-
sed with Morgan, and Offered 10 produce their pa.
pers vouchers of the correctness Of their state
ments This story is improbable and absurd on the
face of IT, But in addition 10 this Gov Clinton has
authorized the editors Of the Albany Daily Adyer-


ser to say that he has received no tidngs Of such
import

Greece DIR. HOWE, an American g.ntleman
who went to Greece, lew years ago, and VINO has
furnished much interesting Information respecting
4 tha, country, says, in letter dated Napo Octo-
*hsr 18th, 896--" cannot forbear 10 repeat, what


had stated in former letters that The worst ioes with
which the Greeks have TO contend are starvation
and nakedncss. The crops in many parts OF The


country are cut off by the operations oi war, and all


the popuation in those parts OF the country occupi

little surplus produce which can be raised viii bare
4 IL be suficen. for he first months OF Winter, and
nothing bur the OF The friends OF Greece, in
Europe. and may not add America, will be able 10
avert all the horrors of famine the ensuing Spring.
Our republication oi Mr.. Harker's opihion OF
4 General JACKSON, as expressed IN the Delaware
Il Gazette whilst the late presidential election was
nrndnp is said to have caused the Corporal great
lea az uneasiness. lie has been bored and twtted

of The General till his whole frame has heen con

any excuse 10 sneak ovt Of the hearing 81 bis up

change, avery sudden change, aud INST wonder
FIJI change for OF all the presses that we arrayed
IN oppo.,tion TO Old Hickory" durln, the contes
for ,he office Of chief magistrate, none were SO ahu
siyr of the Hero none were so Lavish ~ oppeoboas
4 eolhets re specting him, and none displayed M"
$iDyelerae magnty iowa as him. than INC Delawa' c
8Gazcttc Its editor pronounced him the most
objectionable" ot all the candidates, and he deetf
ed ,ha, he had seen In him such disrsge'a for


The Institutions Of the country, such Disposition


N nlocs himself abore its tams and such iRcina
ton to trampe on the rights IF others where they
stood in competiton nith his oWn interest or feet
inrs. as should render The citizens Of the United
States uerY cautious about placing him IN he first
] office mithin their Sitt."


Let the reader bear in mind that the words Just
Quoted we're given by Mr. Harker. as his deliberate
opinion Of Cen Jackson, before the late presioen
,,al ,iectian Let him contrast them with Mr.
Harker's present attempts to promote the cause OF
the General, and he will at once pronounce him to
be the most couie nptbe political weathetcotk that
modern times have produced. But little Will
ago, and General Jackson was, in the opinion O.
Corporal Harker. the "most Objectionable" oil all
the candidates for the presidency; aye, mere " 90
ecuopabe'' than even Messrs Adams shd Clay
who the Corporal would have US believe are the
worst men in the world. Now, the Corporal up
! holds that Z" Objectionable" man as the only one
worthy 10 be elevated to the FIRST office within the
gift OF the people OF the United states. lhe ma"
4 in whom The Corporal has seen "a disregard Tor
the institutions OF his country" is now recommen
ed BY him as the only person into whose hands the


preservation OF those institutions can be safely com
Il nted. The man in whom he has seen " 2 dIspo
si,ion 10 place himself above the laws is now pro-
nounced by him TO be fully qualified to enforce res
\ pect and obedience TO those laws. The man IN
4 whom he has seen " AN inclination to trample on
the rights OF others and to regard no Interest OF
feelings but his own, is now supported oy him as
one who will make greater sacrifices OF his own III
,erest and feelings to the good OF ohers. and be
4 more mindful Of the preservation ct their rights
II than any other man in the Union.


a we have brought these things forward TO try Mr.
Harkcr's honesty-and to try il BY his own rule
Y Some time ago, he declared in his Gazette, tha
those who are honest, and consistent auth the.'

n sight Of what they have done, or said on former
y occasions" Ii sight Of what Mr. Harker ha'
y a sadn on " former occssion,o about Cen Jack

a shame ii has excited other feelings OF very un
pleasant kind and placed him 10 dilemma IRON

a In conclusion, demand OF the Corporal, u ne !

profession" and if he believes that he cannot D.


shamed By sight Of 1chat he has said 10 oomps,
